title: Are Kindle Paperwhites better for your eyes than using a regular tablet? Could I use it frequently without eye strain? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is subjective but yes, after my first Kindle broke I replaced it with a Paper white and I could read it at night and in the day without any problems. The original Kindle was also easy but needed light to read at night but don’t compare Kindles to tablets as Kindles are E-Book readers. Tablets are general purpose systems where speed of display may be a factor. The Kindles are not fast screen updaters; they are fast enough for reading but not for say games) > Kindles have a limited range of shades while a tablet may have to display 16 million colours. So Kindles are perfect for reading thanks to clever use of fonts, typography and most of all the screen display but tablets are not as good for reading but then they were never meant to do just that.

Yes! Kindle paper whites do not use traditional LED screens like you see on your phone or tablet. Instead it uses a technology that Kindle created themselves known as an “E-Ink” display. And though this device still uses LEDs to light the screen, the intensity is much lower than a traditional screen. These devices emit negligible amounts of blue light as well, which make them great for reading before bed when you compare it to a phone or tablet.

Not so bad but, still at risk of eye-strain as mostly related to over-exposure to the near or close-up causing binocular stress maintaining “convergence” of both eyes required to read close-up. Hence the common complaint of CVS or Screen Fatigue now declared a Global Pandemic in DSE user operators by the WHO ICD-10 under the heading of “Asthenopia” a range of repetitive stress injuries manifesting in monocular 2D vision with a loss of perspective / depth of field & thereby judgment of distance.

Absolutely, although obviously, pumping up the light in a dark room will still hurt your eyesight due to the brightness. At this point, one should realize that in a dark room, the light should be very low and subtle, and brightness pumped up in a medium light environment. During normal use, ie daylight, you can keep reading your kindle until you finish your book.
I have never used a tablet, but I use my Kindle several hours a day and I do not strain my eyes. The reason is I can change the print size. This will prevent straining of the eyes.
